comments.text:
I guess I only paid attention to your analogy. So to address your 
"convincing" point: yup they are absolutely forcing people to get health 
care, but it's for the same reason that car insurance is mandatory. Owning 
and operating a car means that you have a chance to cause damage to 
property other than your own. In the case of this event you need to be able 
to afford the repair costs. Same goes for owning a body. One day you get a 
bad injury/illness and can't pay for it, but it's not like we'll just let 
you die, so you get emergency care. That translates into higher premiums 
for everyone else. As an added bonus health insurance means preventative 
care and less chance for costly injuries and illnesses. And while I agree 
with you that there are better ways I would argue that literally anything 
done right now, i'm talking anything, is better than the shitshow system we 
had before. (also given new Affordable Care Act provisions, medicaid is 
expanded and subsidies are given to people that can't afford insurance)

comments.text:
Your kind of situation is one big reason why I'm a proponent of a 
single-payor system like Canada's. Companies and hospitals would work with 
the government, using an 80/20 guideline as a maximum, to fix a procedure 
cost.  Then all medical systems would use that cost.

The federal government, along with the state, would pay the already agreed 
on costs using the entire state as the 'pool'.  And then all the cost 
claims would be worked out by the state in question without interaction 
from the patient at all.

That's how Canada's works, keeps hospitals and doctors private, and 
controls cost while still allowing for profit...AND cover everyone, for 
less money than our taxation in the US alone.

Ours is only going bring coverage and some of the costs (but not all) under 
control.  But still allows for a lot of insurance profiteering.  So, it 
will be awesome for some, still just 'okay' for others (like myself), and 
suck for yet others.  And we still have people who will remain uncovered. 
 But we get to pay higher taxes and higher insurance for it.  :-/

My brother and sister-in-law live with their son in Edmonton, AB...and they 
pay less in taxes there than they did living in the States...and they get 
healthcare rolled in.  And their care there has been better than what they 
previously received in the States too.  Anecdotal, admittedly, but it is 
their experience nonetheless.
comments.author: Evan Marshall

comments.text:

in state or not and whether your situation warrants an emergency.  In my

cardiologists), even though those who know my problem are extremely 
limited.   In fact, I haven't found one.

I hear you, about the insurance companies.  Like any private company, 
they're out to make a profit.  However, a friend who administers our local 
hospital has told me that BCBS pays out 98% for medical expenses in our 
state.  Only two are kept for overhead.  Since he's not employed by them, 
but receives payment from them, I tend to trust his input.  

And in researching costs charged by our insurance providers, they seem very

All I know is that I feel stuck.  And I'm not sure what my church is going 
to do.  They may help with the costs some.  But, like anyone else, they

Thanks for your thoughts.  I'm hoping to get something figured out soon.
comments.author: Kent Sperry

comments.text:
For as much as some insurance companies are complying, there are others 
that are giving the system trouble.  The claim that they have no idea what 
costs will be in 2014 is absurd for at least two reasons:  1. The 
introduction of more people into insurance pools makes cost estimations 
MORE predictable, not less....especially when, 2. healthcare costs haven't 
really risen in the past 3 years.  It would be bizarre that they would 
suddenly jump this year.

Sound like you are getting taken for a ride by the insurance company, which 
is actually what is happening to my sister in Minneapolis too.  Her 
insurance company said they couldn't give her any cost estimates for a 
family plan.  That insurance company is just flatly doing wrong, and it 
doesn't have anything to do with the actual regulations of the ACA.  Just 
scapegoating.

I actually don't know what state you live in anymore.  I hope it isn't one 
that is giving Medicaid expansion problems.  But I was under the impression 
that even Medicaid was supposed to work across state lines, if the medical 
institution in your state referred you to another institution where the 
medical care you need is more readily available.  Here is what I think 
would be the applicable regulation:

42 CFR §431.52, Payments for services furnished out of State.

(a)  Statutory basis Section 1902(a)(16) of the Act authorizes the 
Secretary to prescribe State plan requirements for furnishing Medicaid to 
State residents who are absent from the State.
(b)   Payment for services A State plan must provide that the State will 
pay for services furnished in another State to the same extent that it 
would pay for services furnished within its boundaries if the services are 
furnished to a recipient who is a resident of the State, and any of the 
following conditions is met:

(1)  Medical services are needed because of a medical emergency;
(2)  Medical services are needed and the recipient's health would be 
endangered if he were required to travel to his State of residence;
(3)  The State determines, on the basis of medical advice, that the needed 
medical services, or necessary supplementary resources, are more readily 
available in the other State.
(4)  It is general practice for recipients in a particular locality to use 
medical resources in another State.

(c) Cooperation among States The plan must provide that the State will 
establish procedures to facilitate the furnishing of medical services to 
individuals who are present in the State and are eligible for Medicaid 
under another State's plan.

comments.text:
I've heard this from a number of people I know. It is difficult to 
corroborate, understandably.  Some of my co-workers said their insurance 
was going up by 'thousands'...when in reality their maximum out-of-pocket 
was only increasing by about $500, and their premium also by about $500. 
 Anyway...that is just case here at my workplace.

But, what concerns me with the $7000 increase is that one of the 
regulations is an 80/20 rule.  Insurance companies are required by law to 
demonstrate that they are spending 80% of your premiums on healthcare.  If 
they aren't, then you are entitled to a rebate for the difference. 
Considering that healthcare costs are mostly stagnant right now (and for 
the past 2-3 years) it seems unlikely that a company can truly justify 
needing $7000 more in premiums per year legally.

If you are having this issue with your insurance company, you may want to 
see if they owe you a rebate.

comments.text:
The big advantage of single-payer is right there in the name "single 
payer." Much of the cost our our healthcare system is not in the delivery 
of health care, but in the Byzantine system of insurers, payments, etc. 
every doctor in private practice has to hire multiple full time people just 
to handle the billing. Most doctors have given up private practice or 
become boutique services which don't accept most insurance.

I have been dealing with a seriously ill family member for the past 5 years 
or so, and we spend as much time trying to figure out payments as we do 
figuring out providers and healthcare. Similarly, the billing people at the 
doctors' offices spend more time dealing with the billing than the doctor 
ever spends with a patient. Then, the insurers also spend huge amounts of 
time.

Completely aside from the additional profit that the insurers extract along 
the way, these gross inefficiencies add huge additional costs.

Then, add to the fact that each individual often has multiple payers to 
deal with. Am I paying this with my copay/coinsurance/deductible? Is this 
covered by my medical insurer? By my behavioral health insurer? By my 
dental insurer? By worker's compensation? Just hope that you don't end up 
with seized muscles around your temporary-mandibular joint and worn and 
breaking teeth in your jaw due work-related stress and to poor ergonomics 
from your workplace-provided chair. You will quickly discover that this 
particular malady falls squarely in the gray area between all of those 
payers and everyone wants to pass the buck. (No, this is not the condition 
my family member has).

Despite my supposedly excellent insurance plan and supposed limits on put 
of pocket expenses, I am just a few bills away from bankruptcy due to the 
medical bills from my family member's treatment costs. See, if the insurer 
covers 80% of their "usual and customary rates" (read "the lowest rates 
they have negotiated for in-network providers) for out of network coverage, 
the 20% of UCR counts towards your out of pocket maximum, but the 
difference between UCR and what you are charged does not.

Then, try to actually find out in advance how much a procedure will cost. 
The doctor can't tell you, and refers you to the billing department. 
Billing says they don't know until they see what procedure codes are 
submitted. The doctor doesn't know the procedure codes, and refers you to 
billing. The insurance company won't tell you their UCR unless you give 
them the procedure codes.

*THIS* is the mess that ACA doesn't even touch, but that single-payer would 
solve.

comments.author: Cindy Brown

comments.text:
I'm sorry. I didn't understand that she meant "single payor works best" 
even though there is no proof of that.

The actual problem is that whoever pays isn't relevant. Insurance is a type 
of social finance tool. It uses statistical methods to figure out 
"certainty" and then figures out how much it should charge to pay claims 
plus administration loadings. It's horribly simple. People try to make it 
complicated. It's not.

The system "whips" because of marketing movements that dump vast numbers of 
people whose claims experience is getting worse (or increasing premiums) 
and picks up industries that have young people at more attractive rates. 
But the crucial fact is that people get isolated into islands of 
experience. That's about the worst thing that happens in terms of large 
numbers.

At the level of the medical community, consultants travel and give 
hospitals direction on how to make more money by doing things like changing 
the database so all bed pan charges change to "sterile bed pans" so the 
charge goes from 5 bucks to 40 bucks for example. Or the doctors on the 
board of the hospital make sure that all patients get an MRI no matter what.

I like to think of the medical system in terms of fluid modeling where 
friction generates money and individual doctors can put rocks in the stream.

the only mechanism to get people to buy things.
comments.author: BillyJoe1305

comments.text:
Reputation doesn't mean Jack. People buy from Walmart because it's cheap. 
To resell goods that were sold at a loss wouldn't work because it costs 
money to buy and resell the goods. Who would buy the same more expensive 
goods you resell? Like I also said transportation and products for large 
business is much cheaper so they can afford selling the same products for 
lower prices. The only way some one can break into the market is by 
creating something new, but they would have to do it better than any 
quickly following big business would be able to. Owning 90% of a market is 
a monopoly. Rockefeller was a good businessman because his majority control 
of the market did continue because he was able to cut out competition the 
same way as Blockbuster. A monopoly isn't about 100% ownership, but 100% 
control of a market. There will always be someone attempting to break into 
the market, but that doesn't mean they have the resources necessary to sell 
goods at a competitive price. There can be problems with government, but 
it's still a work in progress. Taft and Roosevelt worked to break up the 
businesses that took advantage of the free market because they were raising 
rates and decreasing wages to an almost unlivable standard.
comments.author: Jerr Bear

comments.text:
But don't bigger companies have much more resources? If a small hardware 
store opens up near a Lowes, Lowes can afford to slash their prices because 
they have other stores that make money, while any competitors resources dry 
up as they loose money to invest. Also big businesses have a network of 
manufactures that provide goods at lower prices based on the sheer bulk of 
goods small business can't afford. Blockbuster did that with mom and pop 
business for years. The only reason Netflix took over was because 
Blockbuster was reluctant to change and close their stores. They could have 
afforded offering cheaper prices for members and more movie titles since 
they had so much more to invest. That doesn't prove the free market works, 
only that sometimes things fall apart. All the free market does is allow 
the rich to get richer and the poor to get poorer. If people didn't act so 
greedy it wouldn't have to be regulated, but it does.
comments.author: Jerr Bear

comments.text:
+Jerr Bear " The problem is, when a small group has control over the 
majority of the goods"  NO. The problem is that often the government will 
use rules and regulations to give a small group a significant advantage in 
the market which places them in control over the majority of the goods. In 
a free market, this is nearly impossible, and even when it does happen, it 
happens because those who are in control offer the best product at the best 
price ... which is GOOD FOR CONSUMERS!

The problem is, when a small group has control over the majority of the 
goods and can manipulate their market to squash competitors, they raise 
prices and lower wages to the point that they flourish and everyone else 
can barely get by. That's why the government regulates business. So we 
don't end up as a dystopia like in The Hunger Games. If you realized, 
almost every story about dystopian societies focus on the few having more 
than the many. Government was created because people tend to be selfish and 
not act in a way that interests the world.
comments.author: Jerr Bear

comments.text:
+Jerr Bear
You obviously have NO IDEA how the free market works, so let me give you a 
summary.PLEASE try to learn something this time. I really hate having to 
teach the same lesson to the same person over and over.

Say I have a bobble, but I'd rather have a dollar. Say you have a dollar 
but you'd rather have a bobble. We each value the other thing more than 
what we have, so we make the trade. THAT is capitalism. BOTH parties walk 
away from every transaction richer than when they started because each 
valued what they got more than what they gave.

Now say I have a factory that makes a billion bobbles, and I sell them all 
for $1. Now I'm rich, but not because I stole a billion dollars from the 
people. I'm rich because I make a billion people richer by a little bit 
each. My greed made other people richer. THAT is how the free market works. 
Free trade benefits all involved. It is not until the government comes in 
with regulations that companies get the power to make trades which are 
disadvantageous to others.
comments.author: ZombieTex

comments.text:
+Jerr Bear
  So we don't we just end the burden of the poor on society and kill them? 
Without the bottom 40% of the unemployed we'd be better off, more than that 
may run into economic trouble when people attempt to improve society, but 
not at the current rate.
  Why don't we have lotteries where we perform medical testing on the names 
drawn from hats and what was wrong with the Tuskegee experiment.
comments.author: BillyJoe1305

comments.text:
Greed doesn't serve anyone well. It's just short sighted egoism. Monopolies 
did have to be broken up by Taft and Roosevelt despite people who were 
duped into thinking the free market was working.

Your reading about the idea of a free market. A free market would be great 
if people were more interested in the wellbeing of everyone, but people 
need laws. The free market isn't free. It's so easily controlled by big 
business that it might as well be run by the government.

All accepted modern philosophers as well as the ancient philosophers (not 
including those who got destroyed in debate such as Callicles) believe it 
is ethical to act in a way that benefits the most people, not in only your 
own self interest.

No one has any authority unless you let them. I did quite a bit of self 
discovery before I realized I didn't want to be the kind of person who 
hoards money, but in reality has no wealth-in character, love, or quality 
of life- or accept a society that allows that.

Unless you seriously think you're the best you can be, you need to open 
your mind up and strive to be better.
comments.author: Jerr Bear

comments.text:
+Jerr Bear "but tends to justify greed" so what? Within a capitalist 
system, the only way to make gain is by providing a service at a price your 
customer wants to pay. The greedier you are, the more you serve the people. 
This is not a bad thing.

"Just because someone has the power to leverage themselves against others 
doesn't make it right." What exactly do you mean?

"The only people who deserve to amass that amount of wealth, use it for to 
better society, not to fill their pockets." And by what authority is that 
determination made? What you have there is an opinion ... just as valid as 
the opposite opinion, and of no more significance. In order for that 
opinion to matter, you must have some authority ... from where is your 
derived?

"Before, government needed to break up monopolies and oligopolies" No, they 
didn't.
Evil Monopolies Are Fairy Tales In Free Markets

"but now it needs to provide equal opportunity for the disenfranchised in a 
different way." No one is disenfranchised by the free market. They are 
disenfranchised by government regulations which prevent the free market 
from providing.

"Imagine having to watch someone you love die despite working more than any 
trust fund baby because you can't afford health care."  Who said life was 
fair? It never has been, and it never will be. Folks need to grow the heck 
up and stop pretending the nanny state can make everyone fair and equal.

After this point there's nothing really to reply to. What you're writing 
doesn't really make any sense. You need to stop reading the leftist 
materials and start doing some actual research into what the free market 
actually is, what it does, and how it actually works. You need to learn the 
difference between Capitalism and Corporatism (also known as Fascism, which 
is what we actually use in the US).
comments.author: ZombieTex

comments.text:
+ZombieTex To Callicles Soctrates said something similar to...Is the 
stronger the smarter, stronger, more in number, or better endowed? 
Capitalism is far from a perfect system. It promotes competition, but tends 
to justify greed. Just because someone has the power to leverage themselves 
against others doesn't make it right. The only people who deserve to amass 
that amount of wealth, use it for to better society, not to fill their 
pockets. Before, government needed to break up monopolies and oligopolies, 
but now it needs to provide equal opportunity for the disenfranchised in a 
different way. Imagine having to watch someone you love die despite working 
more than any trust fund baby because you can't afford health care. How 
about we follow the same system as governments that have a surplus instead 
of a debt. Government run healthcare where better medications are 
prescribed through competition and not the percentage of profit they kick 
back to providers. We could decrease our "defence" budget 10 fold and still 
be stronger than any opposing nation, but part of America's so afraid to 
progress we're lucky we don't still own slaves.
comments.author: Jerr Bear

captions.text:
Hi I'm Dr Aaron Carroll. And in this new youtube
show we are going to try and help you under stand how medical

research and health policy work. We are going
to make sense of a lot of the confusing information

in the world, and we are going to have a lot
of fun doing it.

We are officially launching in a few weeks,
but today, we're going to give you a little

preview., and talk to you about Obamacare.
So I have this friend that is a little bit

of a hypochondriac, his name is John Green.,
and he's been asking me a lot of panicked
questions about Obamacare.

John: Wait Aaron I heard the cost of my families
insurance is going to triple in the next year?.
Aaron: No

John: Well my uncle told me his medicare is
being taken away, thats true, right?
Aaron: That's not going to happen.

John: Alright Aaron, what about this? I heard
that under Obamacare medications are now going
to have side effects.
Aaron: That was already the case.

John: I just got this email from a friend
who said under Obamacare anyone over the age
of 45 will be euthanized.

Aaron: Wow, absolutely not.
John: Also, that reminds me, I just got an

email about someone whose lupus was cured
by Aliens. Why don't we just get our healthcare

from Aliens?
Aaron: Well I suppose...wait NO thats not
how we get healthcare.

Okay, clearly we need to start with the basics.
Let's talk about what Obamacare is, and what

it isn't. And what changes are in store for
you.

Health Care triage
Although Obamacare was passed in 2010, the

big pieces of the law are scheduled to go
into effect on October 1st, just days from

now. But what does that mean to you? Will
your insurance change? Will you still be able

to get medical care? If you don't have insurance
right now, how will you get it? No matter

what you think of the law politically it in
your best interest to get as much out of it

as you can. So today we are going to explain
how Obamacare works, and how it will affect

you.
(Over 47,000,000 Americans were uninsured

in 2012)
For decades the most glaring problem in the

United States healthcare system has been that
millions of people are uninsured. We are one

of the few industrialized countries in the
world that doesn't provide universal coverage

to its citizens. Here is a list of some of
them that do. For the past few years the number

of people that lack any coverage for a year
has hovered around 50 million people. Is that

list still scrolling? We'll wait. By the way
all of those countries are democracies, they
all voted to get that universal coverage.

Lots of people don't have insurance because
they have some form of chronic illness. That's

not a surprise, because I mean come on, if
you're already sick, what insurance company

would want to cover you? And if they do, the
policy that they will give you will likely

cost a fortune. And that's a whole other problem,
health insurance is really really expensive.

Last year the average employer sponsored health
insurance policy cost almost $6000 for an

individual. The average plan for a family,
cost more than $16,000. The average 2 bedroom

apartment rents for about $12,500. I'm just
saying, thats too much money for many americans

to afford.
The architects of Obamacare had a number of

very straightforward goals. The first was
to make sure that no one could be denied insurance

if they wanted to buy it. This idea is called
guaranteed issue. The second is that people

should all be charged a similar amount, even
if they have a chronic condition. They shouldn't

be punished for being sick. This idea is called
community ratings. That's not to be confused

with the TV show community's low ratings,
which are infuriating cause that show is awesome.

These are the major thrusts of Obamacare's
regulations, but there is a problem here.

If you make it so noone can be denied a plan
if they want it, and no one can be forced

to pay more if they're sick; there's no reason
for health people to buy insurance. They can

just wait until they get sick, and then they
can go buy a plan for the same amount that

they could have before they got sick. But
if only sick people buy insurance, then the

price of premiums go way up. This leads to
even more health people to skip buying a plan,

only sick people are left, price goes up even
more, more healthy people opt out, and we

get what we call a death spiral for the private
insurance industry. Which while it sounds

really cool, we really don't want that to
happen.

To avoid this, we need to come up with a way
to convince healthy people to buy insurance.

One way it to charge people a penalty if they
don't. Obamacare handles this by charging

people a fine of $95 or 1% of their income
if they don't buy insurance. That's the individual

mandate, but that creates one more problem.
Who do you make people pay for something if

they can't afford it? One way would be to
subsidize it. And people who make less that

400% of the poverty line, will get a tax credit
from federal government to help them pay for

the insurance. These are the subsidies of
Obamacare.

These three factors , the regulations, the
individual mandate, and the subsidies from

the three-legged stool of Obamacare. The reason
we call it that is because it only works if

it is balanced. Remove anyone of the legs
and the stool is going to fall over. Remove

any one of these three things from Obamacare
and the law would just fall apart. So that's

how Obamacare works. It also happens to be
pretty much how Massachusetts's health care

system works. And Switzerland's for that matter.
And those systems are working pretty well.

I mean have you seen the healthy glow of those
swiss people and bostonians?

But what will all of this mean to you? You,
like John, may have heard some pretty nasty

scary things about Obamacare. But here are
the facts. If you are 65 or older and you

have medicare, nothing will change for you.
By which I mean you keep your medicare, nothing

changes. You need to sign up for nothing on
October 1st.

If you have insurance from you Job, or from
someone in your family, then it's very very

likely that nothing will change for you either.
Most people in the United States get their

insurance this way, and you will continue
to do so next year too. You also need to do
nothing, on October 1st.

If you get your insurance from medicaid, or
from the veterans administration, or from

some other government source. Then nothing
will change for you either. You'll still get

your insurance from the government and you
too need to do nothing, on October 1st.

That leaves the group of people who really
need to pay attention to what's coming up

on October 1st. And those are legal citizens
who are uninsured right now, or thing they

might be uninsured next year. That's who Obamacare
is really going to affect, and there are just

over 30 million of you. You should go to www.healthcare.gov.
That's been set up to help you get insurance

that you are going to be required to have
in 2014. The site will ask you a few simple

questions, and use that information to make
some recommendations for you for insurance.

If you make less than 133% of the poverty
line, you'll qualify for medicaid., which

is free. Some states unfortunately aren't
participation in the medicaid expansion which

will be a problem for very poor people in
those states., but that's still in flux. Everyone

else will go to the insurance exchanges. Where
companies will offer plans at bronze, silver,

gold, and platinum levels. The more you're
willing to pay, the more robust your coverage

will be. But it's your choice. If you make
less that 400% of the poverty line, you'll

get a subsidy to help with the premiums. And
the vast vast majority of people who are uninsured

in the united states are going to get those
subsidies. And for many of them the bronze

level plans will be pretty affordable.
And that's it! There are other bells and whistles

to Obamacare, and we'll be covering them in
future episodes., but this is what you need

to know right now to get ready for 2014. So
whether you like the idea of Obamacare or

you hate it., it's coming on October 1st.
You owe it to yourself to at least take a

look and consider your options . Go to healthcare.gov
and see how much insurance is going to cost

you. It's not going to be as scary as you've
been told. Even if it's not as awesome as
getting health care from aliens.
